IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: JA empowers young people to own their econom success through volunteer-delivered prgrms which give students knowledge & skills in finan lit, work readiness & entrepreneurship.
IRS990.MissionDesc: TO INSPIRE AND PREPARE YOUNG PEOPLE TO SUCCEED IN A GLOBAL ECONOMY. SEE ADDITIONAL MISSION INFORMATION ON SCHEDULE O.
IRS990.Desc: The organization is focused on scaling the delivery of a modified version of our traditional JA Company program to very poor, out-of-school, underemployed/unemployed youth (typically between the ages of 15-35) to create sustainable micro-enterprises and jobs.

Form990ScheduleAPartVIGrp.ExplanationTxt: Other Income: Foreign Currency Exchange Loss 69

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Trust, Escrow, and Custodial Arrangements: The Organization assists its affiliates around the world in setting up their own organizations to administer Junior Achievement programs. The Organization holds funds on behalf of these affiliates for their expenses. The organization holds cash to satisfy the funds held of $145,969.

UNCERTAIN TAX POSITIONS: Management has evaluated their income tax positions under the guidance included in ASC 740. Based on their review, management has not identified any material uncertain tax positions to be recorded or disclosed in the financial statements.
Book and tax difference: Revenue of Entities consolidated in financials, excluded for 990 purposes 6,548,339
Book and tax difference: Designated contribution to member nations treated as agency transactions for financial statement purposes 452,618*
Book and tax difference: Expense of entities consolidated in financials, excluded for 990 purposes 7,288,496

Book Tax Difference: Designated Contributions to member nations treated as Agency Transactions for financial statement purposes 452,618* *The organization assumes acknowledgment responsibility for these grants. This is the most efficient approach with numerous member nations benefitting from an indvidual grant. Therefore, the organization includes the grant revenue and grant expense on form 990.

Organization's procedures for monitoring the use of grant funds: Grants are to JA or member nations only. Most of the funding for the grants are provided by donors who place restrictions on the use of the monies. Grant usage requirements varies by donor. The reporting required is submitted to the organizations grant steward or directly to the donor.

Executive Compensation: COMPENSATION IS PAID THROUGH A RELATED ORGANIZATION, JA WORLDWIDE, INC. PLEASE SEE SCHEDULE O, LINE 15A AND 15B DISCLOSURE REGARDING HOW COMPENSATION IS DETERMINED FOR THE CEO.

ORGANIZATION'S MISSION CONT. Junior Achievement is the world's largest organization dedicated to giving young people the knowledge and skills they need to own their economic success, plan for their future, and make smart academic and economic choices. Our financial literacy, work readiness and entrepreneurship programs empower students to make a connection between what they learn in school and how it can be applied in the real world. This enhances the relevance of their classroom learning and increases their understanding of the value of staying in school.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 2
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FAMILY AND BUSINESS RELATIONSHIPS: THE FOLLOWING PERSONS ARE ALL EMPLOYEES OF A RELATED ORGANIZATION AND THEREFORE HAVE A BUSINESS RELATIONSHIP: *Asheesh Advani, CEO - JA Worldwide *Margie Wang, COO-CFO - JA Worldwide *Elizabeth Bintliff, CEO - JA AFRICA

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 6, 7A, & 7B
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: MEMBERS: THE SOLE MEMBER OF JA AFRICA, INC. (JAA) SHALL BE JA WORLDWIDE, INC. WHICH HAS THE RIGHT TO ELECT AND REMOVE DIRECTORS. THE FOLLOWING ACTIONS REQUIRE APPROVAL BY THE MEMBER: 1) AMENDMENT, MODIFICATION, OR RESTATEMENT OF THE CERTIFICATE OR BYLAWS; 2) MERGER, CONSOLIDATION, REORGANIZATION, OR DISSOLUTION OF JAA OR THE SALE, LEASE OR EXCHANGE, OR OTHER DISPOSITION, TRANSFER OR CONVEYANCE OF ALL OR SUBSTANTIALLY ALL OF ITS ASSETS; 3) ANY MATERIAL CHANGE IN ANY CURRENT NONPROFIT PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVES OF JAA; 4) ENTERING INTO ANY OPERATING AGREEMENT BETWEEN JAA AND ANY OF ITS LOCAL AREAS, OTHER THAN IN SUBSTANTIALLY THE FORM PREVIOUSLY APPROVED BY THE MEMBER, OR MODIFYING OR AMENDING TO ANY MATERIAL EXTENT ANY SUCH OPERATING AGREEMENT IN A MANNER SUBSTANTIALLY INCONSISTENT WITH SUCH FORM.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: PROCESS TO REVIEW THE FORM 990: THE FORM 990 IS PREPARED BY A THIRD PARTY AND IS REVIEWED BY THE AUDIT COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD. A DRAFT IS SUPPLIED VIA A WEB SITE LINK FOR THE ENTIRE BOARD TO REVIEW BEFORE FILING THE FINAL 990 WITH THE IRS.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: PROCESS FOR MONITORING COMPLIANCE WITH CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY: ALL OFFICERS, DIRECTORS, AND EMPLOYEES ARE REQUIRED ANNUALLY TO COMPLETE AND UPDATE A CONFLICT OF INTEREST DECLARATION AS A METHOD OF DISCLOSING AND ETHICALLY RESOLVING POTENTIAL CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. SHOULD ANY TRANSACTION OR ACT OF ANY OFFICER, DIRECTOR, AND EMPLOYEE CONSTITUTE A POSSIBLE CONFLICT OF INTEREST, THE INDIVIDUAL IS REQUIRED TO DISCLOSE ALL THE RELEVANT FACTS FOR CONSIDERATION TO DETERMINE WHETHER A CONFLICT OF INTEREST ACTUALLY EXISTS, AND IF SO, THE MANNER IN WHICH IT SHOULD BE RESOLVED.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15a & 15B
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: DESCRIBE PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION: The governance process for determining compensation for the Organization's CEO and other top management is modeled after the requirements in Internal Revenue Code Section 4958 to establish the presumption of reasonable compensation. Compensation was reviewed and approved by the Executive Compensation Subcommittee (the Committee) of the Board of Governors of JA Worldwide, Inc., which is comprised of independent persons. By engaging an independent compensation consultant, the Committee considered comparable market data from published surveys and Form 990 of comparable organizations in evaluating the compensation for each individual. The Committee conducted a review of this comparability data and documented its deliberation and discussion in minutes that are retained with the other governance materials of the Organization. The Committee followed the process to establish the presumption that compensation paid to the Organization's CEO and other top management for purposes of Section 4958 by relying on professional advice in the written opinion of reasonableness from the independent compensation consultant, Towers Watson. This review process is conducted annually and was last done in 2018.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: GOVERNING DOCUMENTS AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC: JA AFRICA MAKES ITS FINANCIAL STATEMENTS, GOVERNING DOCUMENTS, AND CONFLICT OF INTEREST POLICY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC UPON REQUEST.

COMPENSATION: Compensation for Asheesh Advani and Margie Wang are for services as employees of JA Worldwide, Inc., a related organization. Compensation deliberations take into account services provided to the filing organization and its affiliates. Revenue presented in the Form 990 does not include the revenue of the 118 JA affiliates who are part of the global JA network that JA Worldwide oversees. In FYE 2018, revenue of all affiliates totaled $329,749.807.
